article:
The 'International Linear Collider' ('ILC') is a proposed linear particle
accelerator. {{cite web
| title = The International Linear Collider â Gateway to the Quantum Universe
| url = http://www.linearcollider.org/cms/?pid=1000446 date = 2007-10-18
| accessdate = 2009-05-21 publisher = ILC Community format = PDF
}} It is planned to have a collision energy of 500 GeV initially, with the
possibility for a later upgrade to 1000 GeV (1 TeV). The host country for the
accelerator has not yet been chosen and proposed locations are Japan, Europe
(CERN) and the USA (Fermilab). {{cite web
| url = http://physicsworld.com/blog/2012/02/where_should_the_international.html
| title = Where should the International Linear Collider be built? author=Hamish
| Johnston publisher = physicsworld.com accessdate = 2012-08-02
}} Japan is considered the most likely candidate, as the Japanese
government is willing to contribute half of the costs, according to a
representative for the European Commission on Future
Accelerators. {{cite web
| title = The new particle accelerator ILC will not be completed before 2026,
| says FranÃ§ois Richard (spanish) url = http://www.uimp.es/blogs/prensa/2012/06/11/el-nuevo-acelerador-de-particulas-
| ilc-no-estara-finalizado-antes-de-2026-segun-francois-richard/ date = 2012-06-
| 11 accessdate = 2012-08-02
}} Construction could begin in 2015 or 2016 and will not be completed
before 2026. {{cite web
| url = http://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/acelerador-ilc-buscar-bos%C3%B3n-higgs-listo-
| 2026-140600354.html title = The ILC accelerator to search for the Higgs boson
| will not be ready before 2026 (spanish) date = 2012-06-11 publisher = Yahoo
}}

Studies for an alternative project called CLIC the Compact Linear Collider are
also underway, which would operate at higher energies (up to 3 TeV) in a machine
with comparable length as the ILC.

The ILC would collide electrons with positrons. It will be between 30 km
and 50 km (19â31 mi.) long, more than 10 times as long as the 50
GeV Stanford Linear Accelerator, the longest existing linear particle
accelerator. The proposal is based on previous similar proposals from Europe,
the U.S., and Japan.
headings: Merging of regional proposals into a worldwide project
